results.title: Love is in the air. Ep. 3
results.creator_credit: Paul Clarke, Greg Appel and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Love is in the air”.
Love is in the air is an entertaining series about the history of Australian music on television. This episode largely celebrates the great ABC pop show from the 1970s “Countdown”. Coming out of left field “Countdown” was a deliberate attempt by national broadcaster ABC to court teenagers, and they responded with gusto. The show became so enormously popular that it gained iconic status; whilst at the same time gave many acts their big break. Such acts, featured on this episode include: Sherbet, Skyhooks, John Paul Young, Marcia Hines, and Split Enz. “Countdown” also attracted high-calibre international guests like Elton John, Rod Steward and Madonna. Ian “Molly” Meldrum the show’s irreverent presenter and talent scout became an international personality. Australian variety television shows of the 1950s, and 1960s, celebrating yodelling, slap-stick and vaudevillian artists, paved the way for “Countdown”, which certainly shared with its predecessors an anarchic spirit, and passion for showcasing distinctly Australian culture. Made up of an array of interviews from past alumni, this episode features a heap of excerpts from the “Countdown”, including memorable clips, songs and interviews.

results.title: Love is in the air
results.creator_credit: Paul Clarke and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Using archival footage and contemporary interviews, this fascinating five part series tells of the history of popular music in Australia. Not only did some home-grown stars and songs make it big locally but proved to be just as successful overseas - especially Australian women.

results.title: Children's thought and language
results.creator_credit: Michael Forlong Productions and Stefan Sargent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Looking at Research”.
The film outlines a project sponsored by the Social Science Research Council to study childhood development of intelligence and to discover how much children understand.

results.title: Back room of the sky
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of work carried out at the Ministry of Aviation Research Centre at Boscombe Down. Aiming always for increased safety and efficiency, all sections of a new aircraft must be rigorously tested and teams of pilots, scientists and engineers seek out any flaws which must be corrected before a machine becomes operational. The men who will fly the aircraft are also seen undergoing tests at Boscombe Down. Narrated by Raymond Baxter.

group_siblings.title: Look at life: Bronze silver and gold

results.title: Silver's new shine
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
Today silver plays a new role in Britain. Since 1947 it has ceased to be used in British coinage and is put to work more and more widely in a variety of industries. Old silver coins are refined at the Royal Mint, to supply industry with more of this precious mineral, also used in the fine silver work for which Britain’s silversmith’s are traditionally famous.

group_siblings.title: Look at life: Bronze silver and gold

results.title: Rising to high office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
The Shell office in London, 26 floors high is like a small boom town. Shops, restaurant, hair dressing salon and recreation facilities are readily available to all staff. There is an automatic mail dispatch with receiving lines on each floor; audio typists receive letters from all over the building without leaving their desks; the switchboard operates 250 lines with some 4,000 extensions. Narrated by Tim Turner.

group_siblings.title: Look at life: Bronze silver and gold

results.title: Meet the mayor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
Gives an account of the duties of a mayor and records some colourful civic ceremonies. Mayors have been an integral part of British national and civic life for generations. Today there are 430 mayors in Britain, each elected by citizens to serve their community.
